articles.title: Sun spits filaments out from 'canyon of fire' as aurora forecast remains strong - Space.com
articles.description: The "canyon of fire" is at least 12,400 miles (20,000 kilometers) deep and 10 times as long.
articles.content:
Filaments of plasma escaped from a fiery canyon that opened on the sun's surface on Sunday (April 3) releasing powerful streams of magnetized solar wind

articles.author: Jonathan Chadwick
articles.title: Gigantic Jupiter-like alien planet observed still 'in the womb' - Daily Mail
articles.description: Researchers used Hubble data going back to 2007, as well as the Subaru Telescope near the summit of an inactive Hawaiian volcano, to detect and study the planet.
articles.content:
The Hubble Space Telescope has found a planet nine times the mass of Jupiter that is still 'in the womb', NASA has announced. 
The newly forming planet, called AB Aurigae b, is a gas giant in a rema… [+8085 chars]

articles.author: Michelle Starr
articles.title: Mars Is Rumbling With Mysterious Quakes We've Never Detected Before - ScienceAlert
articles.description: It turns out that Mars is rumblier than we knew. New techniques have revealed previously undetected quakes beneath the Martian surface – and, scientists say, the best explanation so far is ongoing volcanic activity.

articles.title: ISS photo taken from the ground shows two astronauts performing a spacewalk - Daily Mail
articles.description: The photo, taken by award-winning German photographer Sebastian Voltmer, is believed to be the first ground-based image of two ISS astronauts spacewalking.
articles.content:
When it comes to mesmerising images of space, we're more accustomed to those taken by astronauts, probes or iconic telescopes such as Hubble.
